thread.title: Debutant called on as Lynnsanity hits hurdle
thread.title_full: Debutant called on as Lynnsanity hits hurdle

title: Debutant called on as Lynnsanity hits hurdle
text:
Chris Lynn has been ruled out of the rest of the BBL as well as the ODI series in New Zealand Staff writers and AAP, AAP January 18, 2017 3:46pm 
BIG Bash sensation Chris Lynn has been ruled out for the rest of the series against Pakistan, the BBL and the upcoming one-day tour of New Zealand because of a neck injury. 
Australia coach Darren Lehmann confirmed Lynn’s injury setback at the same time as announcing Peter Handscomb as the team’s latest ODI debutant this series. 
Handscomb will join the XI along with fast bowler Billy Stanlake, who comes in for the rested Mitchell Starc for Thursday’s third ODI at the WACA Ground. 
Lynn made his ODI debut in the series-opening win over Pakistan on January 13, but the pain from a bulging disc in his neck has gotten worse and he’s been ordered to rest. media_camera Chris Lynn has been troubled by the neck injury. Pic: Darren England. 
Lynn’s exit — along with that of all-rounder Mitchell Marsh who will miss the rest of the Pakistan series with a shoulder injury — opens the door for Handscomb to slot into the crucial No.4 batting role. 
Lehmann is hopeful Lynn will return for the home T20 series against Sri Lanka, starting on February 17. 
“He’s been playing through a lot of pain even during the BBL and he’s got to the stage where he can’t function anymore,” coach Darren Lehmann said in Perth. 
“He’ll have a couple of weeks of no cricket ... he’s got to calm down the neck because it’s quite aggravated. 
“He’ll start his rehab now and he won’t be doing too much strenuous stuff before he hopefully gets back for the Sri Lankan series.” media_camera Peter Handscomb had an instant impact in Test cricket. 
Handscomb made an immediate impact during the Test summer, averaging an extraordinary 99.75 through his first four Tests as he notched two centuries and two half-centuries. 
“He’s done really well, he’s been outstanding. it’s good reward for a good summer,” Lehmann said of Handscomb. 
“Obviously we want four quality batters going at the top. He’ll get his chance there. 
“It’s unlucky for Chris Lynn (but) that number four spot is there and Peter has done a really good job in the Test match for us, so he gets another crack at it.” 
Although not renowned for being a blaster, Handscomb showcased his one- day potential with an unbeaten 40 off 25 balls during Australia’s pursuit of quick runs in their SCG Test win over Pakistan. 
“He played a very good one-day sort of innings for us in the Sydney Test match where we scored quite quickly,” Lehmann said. 
“So he’s got all the shots and he’s quite innovative. 
“He’s done outstanding. It’s good reward for a good summer.” 
Stanlake made his ODI debut in the series-opening win at the Gabba. But a bout of illness meant he could only bowl three overs before he was forced from the field. 
Lehmann has high hopes for what the 204cm paceman can achieve at the WACA Ground. 
“He’s tall and he’s got some bounce, so we think he will be quite effective here,” Lehmann said. 
Spinner Adam Zampa and allrounder Marcus Stoinis were the unlucky players to miss out on a spot in the XI.
